awd_titl_txt: CIF: Small: Algebraic Network Information Theory
awd_abstract_narration:
The demand for data services has grown exponentially over the past decade, driven by data-hungry applications such as mobile video, and is forecasted to accelerate through the next decade. To keep up with this demand, new infrastructure is being built at a rapid pace, leading to denser, more complex deployments. Concurrently, mobile processing power has increased dramatically, which opens the door for the inclusion of more sophisticated communication techniques as part of developing standards. Within this context, network information theory acts as a powerful theoretical framework for assessing techniques across complex network topologies and setting benchmarks for practical deployments. Recent efforts have uncovered examples of techniques that sit outside this classical framework, and exploit the algebraic structure inherent to multi-user communication to attain higher performance. This project will develop an algebraic network information theory that unifies classical and modern communication techniques, and can serve as a foundation for future information-processing networks. The project is complemented by several educational and outreach activities, including workshops, summer schools, and tutorials.

This project aims to take a comprehensive view of algebraic, information-theoretic techniques for efficient communication across networks. The overarching goal is to develop an algebraic network information theory starting from the accessible concepts of joint typicality and discrete memoryless channels and sources. The project is organized into three thrusts. The first thrust outlines a unifying problem statement based on joint typicality as well as algebraic packing and covering lemmas. The second thrust pursues a fundamental understanding of the limits of optimal decoding. Finally, the third thrust aims to transport geometric insights from lattice-based codes to obtain new bounds and algorithms for linear codes.

por.por_cntn:
In a communications network, it is often the case that simultaneous transmissions by nearby users result in interference from the perspective of the receiver. While this interference has historically been treated as a nuisance to be avoided, recent efforts have demonstrated, both in theory and in practice, that interference can be harnessed as part of a communication strategy. Specifically, it is often possible for the receiver to recover a linear combination of the transmitted packets at a higher data rate than would be possible for recovering packets individually. These linear combinations can then be used for an end-to-end network communication protocol, such as network coding where the goal is to recover enough linear combinations to solve for the packets of interest.

Prior work in this domain relied primarily on carefully-tailored linear code constructions, such as nested lattice codes, in order to demonstrate the viability and performance of decoding linear combinations for a specific channel. In contrast, most of the literature on information and coding theory relies on the probabilistic framework of typical sequences in order to simultaneously establish performance limits for a wide range of channel models. This typicality framework has many advantages including clear statements of performance limits via entropy and mutual information, and the availability of powerful coding techniques and typicality-based bounds. The main objective of this project was to bring concepts and techniques for decoding linear combinations of data packets into the typicality framework. This required establishing new mathematical bounds and techniques for handling random linear codes via typicality, and ultimately resulted in a concise description of the performance limits via entropy constraints. Moreover, in the conventional typicality framework, performance limits are usually first determined for channels with finite alphabets, and then extended to continuous channels using limit arguments. In this project, a similar limit-based approach was utilized to extend results from the finite alphabet case to the continuous case, which also required the development of new bounds and techniques.

Another topic investigated via this project was the design of scalar quantizers to maximize the retention of mutual information. Consider a scenario where a device observes a noisy version of a measurement of interest, and wishes to compress this observation into a few bits for later use. This scenario has been thoroughly investigated in the literature when the objective is to reconstruct the measurement to minimize the mean-squared error, or a similar loss function. This project sought instead to characterize the performance limits when the goal is maximize the mutual information between the reconstruction and the measurement. Upper and lower bounds on the number of required bits to preserve a certain fraction of the mutual information were established. 

As part of this project, two PhD students and one postdoctoral scholar were trained as experts in information theory.  The findings of this project were reported via conference and journal papers, a book chapter, and invited seminars.
